body: Update: added note on potential legal ramifications.

We could use more `@author` tags inside the header of the source file. That way, there wouldn't be a lot of `@author` tags inside actual code that may remain there even though someone else changed some parts of it.

rename.from: Honor contributors by permitting @author tags in Java source code
rename.to: Include @author tags in Java source code

body: Or how about a custom tag `@contributor`? [They seem to be doable](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2677564/how-to-create-custom-javadoc-tags) We would just have to modify gradle build ðŸ˜‰

@sbrannen Would the addition of `@author` tags be applicable to contributors such as myself who made contributions in the past but, in light of this issue, would quite like their past contributions to be properly attributed as well?

@slu-it I agree with the fact that they eventually turn into lies. Isn't it because nobody ensures that they stay up to date? I see these `@author` tags in most of the files from the work and they don't add very much value to the code. 

@sbrannen Perhaps we can have some gradle task to run and dynamically generate the `@author`/`@contributor` tags by looking at who commited changes to a file and at which lines (in case more precision is needed ðŸ˜„). When the person does not have any more changes there, that person should be removed. (not really sure about removal, whether is okay, but it might work)

Now that @slu-it mentions it, I think I actually agree with his viewpoint on this.

IIRC, Google is currently in the process of removing `@author` tags from their Java open source projects, because they don't accurately reflect who initially wrote certain source files and who made additions/changes/deletions to particular areas in those source files over time (I think because `@author` tags are easily missed and so aren't updated often; they're not granular enough for certain source code changes; and in Google's case their version control system is good enough for figuring out who did what).

So I'd be tempted to follow Google's example.

Although having said that, @Andrei94's idea of generating `@contributor` tags automatically sounds neat to me in theory, so I'd be interested to see it developed further. It may turn out to be practical, it may turn out not to be. But if it does turn out to be practical, then it may make contributor's efforts more visible (leaving people who are interested to learn more to use appropriate tools to dig into the git history).

Regarding the potential legal ramifications of _not_ including `@author` tags, well that's a tricky area where I have little to no experience, as (admittedly) my understanding of EPL 1.0 is far from comprehensive... :thinking:
How do companies like IBM (who use EPL 1.0 IIRC) deal with this situation?
